The new Action Plan to Combat Energy Poverty will be published shortly. The Plan will set out measures that are being implemented this winter, as well as key longer-term measures to ensure that those least able to afford increased energy costs are supported and protected.

We are also working with the European Investment Bank and the Strategic Banking Corporation of Ireland to develop a loan guarantee to underpin a new Low-Cost Loan Scheme. Loans will be available under the scheme in Q1 next year.

We‚Äôre working hard on ensuring the market can increase capacity, by increasing the workforce through better & more targeted training courses.There have been 1,238 NZEB course starters so far this year across 5 centres.¬† There was a record number of new apprenticeships last year.

OSSs have seen huge demand, more than it can cater for right now. Contractors are expanding in number & capacity. But it is important to note that OSS is only one delivery channel of home energy upgrades. https://t.co/firw2SK4DZ

This new One Stop Shop service launched earlier this year with the first OSS being ready for applications in April. It‚Äôs a whole house service, some offer financing, to streamline the customer journey. Many other EU countries following the OSS model. https://t.co/CfDpF73vsX

We‚Äôre supporting homeowners to undertake deeper retrofits.This is essential to our climate targets.  So far this year 5,260 homes have been upgraded to a B2 level and we expect at least 8,500 for the full year, 1,200 expected in the new OSS scheme.

We‚Äôve increased attic and cavity wall grants to 80% of the typical cost, open for all homes as these are the quickest, easiest & most cost-effective measures. There are still lots of homes that need these upgrades üëáüëáüëá  https://t.co/jCsMBoiybZ

Last year, 2,100 fully funded upgrades were provided under the Warmer Homes Scheme. We will deliver 4,800 upgrades under the scheme this year with 6,000 upgrades next year. The average cost of retrofits provided under the Scheme so far this year is ‚Ç¨18,750.

Supporting lower income households is central. Financial allocations for our dedicated energy poverty (100% funded) schemes operated by SEAI and Local Authorities ‚Äì 61% of the total. Another 5-10% for low income homes in Communities & OSS ( One Stop Shop) https://t.co/zjyfVlPbj5

Government funds a range of supports for all types of households: Individual energy upgrade grants for step-by-step retrofits (~10k this year); One Stop Shop end to end service; Community scheme for aggregation; fully funded upgrades for energy poor & local authority homes.

Exchequer investment of ‚Ç¨8bn to 2030 will create thousands of quality jobs. Last year we spent ‚Ç¨101 million on @SEAI_ie supported retrofit. The budget for this year is ‚Ç¨244m and a record allocation of ‚Ç¨337m is in place for 2023. https://t.co/nycgo5vF6F

We are scaling up from 15,500 home energy upgrades last year to 27,000 this year and 37,000 in 2023. We‚Äôre building towards delivering 75,000 home upgrades a year from 2026. The project will take 30 years, like the installation of central heating did in the 1970‚Äôs, 80‚Äôs and 90s.

Home energy upgrades are a key tool to reduce energy bills, address energy poverty, improve energy security & decrease emissions.  I gave an update of our 30 year national retrofit plan at the Irish Retrofit conference today. We‚Äôre delivering üßµüëáüëá  https://t.co/i3Xzk9Egtv https://t.co/kAzekyBksM

Belisha beacons can cost close to ‚Ç¨80,000 to install and can be delayed by issues with connection to an electricity source. By removing these obstacles,local authorities will be able to roll out pedestrian crossings more easily & quickly.
